sections.title: Node.js Fundamentals
sections.description: Learn the basics of Node.js and server-side JavaScript

lessons.title: Welcome to Node.js
lessons.description: Introduction to Node.js and its ecosystem

lessons.title: Setting Up Node.js
lessons.description: Install Node.js and set up your development environment
lessons.content:
What is Node.js?

Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. It allows you to run JavaScript on the server.

Installation

  1. Download Node.js from nodejs.org
  2. Install the LTS (Long Term Support) version
  3. Verify installation: node --version and npm --version

Your First Node.js Program

// hello.js
console.log('Hello, Node.js!');

// Run with: node hello.js

Node.js REPL

The REPL (Read-Eval-Print-Loop) is an interactive shell:

$ node
> 2 + 2
4
> const name = 'Node'
> console.log(`Hello, ${name}!`)
Hello, Node!

lessons.title: Understanding Modules
lessons.description: Learn about CommonJS and ES modules
lessons.content:
CommonJS Modules

Node.js uses CommonJS module system by default:

// math.js
function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

function subtract(a, b) {
  return a - b;
}

module.exports = { add, subtract };

// app.js
const math = require('./math');
console.log(math.add(5, 3)); // 8

ES Modules

Modern JavaScript modules (requires .mjs extension or "type": "module" in package.json):

// math.mjs
export function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

export function subtract(a, b) {
  return a - b;
}

// app.mjs
import { add, subtract } from './math.mjs';
console.log(add(5, 3)); // 8

Built-in Modules

const fs = require('fs');
const path = require('path');
const http = require('http');
const os = require('os');

lessons.title: Working with the File System
lessons.description: Read and write files with Node.js

sections.title: Express.js Framework
sections.description: Build web applications and APIs with Express.js

lessons.title: Introduction to Express.js
lessons.description: Learn the basics of the Express framework
lessons.content:
What is Express.js?

Express is a minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework that provides a robust set of features for web and mobile applications.

Installation

npm install express

Creating a Basic Server

const express = require('express');
const app = express();
const port = 3000;

app.get('/', (req, res) => {
  res.send('Hello, Express!');
});

app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Server running at http://localhost:${port}`);
});

Routing

app.get('/users', (req, res) => {
  res.json({ message: 'Get all users' });
});

app.post('/users', (req, res) => {
  res.json({ message: 'Create a user' });
});

app.put('/users/:id', (req, res) => {
  res.json({ message: `Update user ${req.params.id}` });
});

app.delete('/users/:id', (req, res) => {
  res.json({ message: `Delete user ${req.params.id}` });
});

lessons.title: Middleware in Express
lessons.description: Understand and use middleware functions

lessons.title: Request and Response Objects
lessons.description: Work with HTTP requests and responses
lessons.content:
Request Object (req)

The request object contains information about the HTTP request:

app.get('/user/:id', (req, res) => {
  // Route parameters
  console.log(req.params.id);

  // Query parameters (?name=John&age=25)
  console.log(req.query.name);
  console.log(req.query.age);

  // Request headers
  console.log(req.headers['content-type']);

  // Request body (requires body-parser middleware)
  console.log(req.body);
});

Response Object (res)

The response object is used to send a response to the client:

// Send plain text
res.send('Hello World');

// Send JSON
res.json({ name: 'John', age: 25 });

// Set status code
res.status(404).send('Not Found');

// Redirect
res.redirect('/login');

// Send file
res.sendFile('/path/to/file.pdf');

Parsing Request Bodies

// Built-in middleware
app.use(express.json()); // Parse JSON bodies
app.use(express.urlencoded({ extended: true })); // Parse URL-encoded bodies

app.post('/users', (req, res) => {
  console.log(req.body); // Access parsed body
  res.json(req.body);
});

lessons.title: Quiz: Express.js
lessons.description: Test your knowledge of Express framework

sections.title: Building REST APIs
sections.description: Create RESTful APIs with Express and Node.js

lessons.title: REST API Principles
lessons.description: Understand RESTful architecture and best practices

lessons.title: Creating CRUD Endpoints
lessons.description: Build Create, Read, Update, Delete operations
lessons.content:
RESTful CRUD Operations

HTTP MethodEndpointDescription
GET/api/postsGet all posts
GET/api/posts/:idGet a single post
POST/api/postsCreate a new post
PUT/api/posts/:idUpdate a post
DELETE/api/posts/:idDelete a post

Example Implementation

const express = require('express');
const router = express.Router();

// In-memory data store (use database in production)
let posts = [
  { id: 1, title: 'First Post', content: 'Hello World' },
  { id: 2, title: 'Second Post', content: 'Learning Node.js' }
];

// GET all posts
router.get('/posts', (req, res) => {
  res.json(posts);
});

// GET single post
router.get('/posts/:id', (req, res) => {
  const post = posts.find(p => p.id === parseInt(req.params.id));
  if (!post) return res.status(404).json({ error: 'Post not found' });
  res.json(post);
});

// CREATE post
router.post('/posts', (req, res) => {
  const newPost = {
    id: posts.length + 1,
    title: req.body.title,
    content: req.body.content
  };
  posts.push(newPost);
  res.status(201).json(newPost);
});

// UPDATE post
router.put('/posts/:id', (req, res) => {
  const post = posts.find(p => p.id === parseInt(req.params.id));
  if (!post) return res.status(404).json({ error: 'Post not found' });

  post.title = req.body.title;
  post.content = req.body.content;
  res.json(post);
});

// DELETE post
router.delete('/posts/:id', (req, res) => {
  const index = posts.findIndex(p => p.id === parseInt(req.params.id));
  if (index === -1) return res.status(404).json({ error: 'Post not found' });

  posts.splice(index, 1);
  res.status(204).send();
});

module.exports = router;

lessons.title: Error Handling and Validation
lessons.description: Implement proper error handling and input validation
lessons.content:
Input Validation with express-validator

npm install express-validator
const { body, validationResult } = require('express-validator');

router.post('/users',
  // Validation rules
  body('email').isEmail().normalizeEmail(),
  body('password').isLength({ min: 6 }),
  body('name').trim().notEmpty(),
  
  // Handler
  (req, res) => {
    const errors = validationResult(req);
    if (!errors.isEmpty()) {
      return res.status(400).json({ errors: errors.array() });
    }

    // Create user...
    res.json({ message: 'User created' });
  }
);

Centralized Error Handling

// Error handling middleware (must be last)
app.use((err, req, res, next) => {
  console.error(err.stack);
  
  res.status(err.status || 500).json({
    error: {
      message: err.message,
      status: err.status || 500
    }
  });
});

// Usage
app.get('/error-example', (req, res, next) => {
  const error = new Error('Something went wrong');
  error.status = 400;
  next(error);
});

Async Error Handling

// Wrapper for async routes
const asyncHandler = (fn) => (req, res, next) => {
  Promise.resolve(fn(req, res, next)).catch(next);
};

router.get('/posts', asyncHandler(async (req, res) => {
  const posts = await Post.find();
  res.json(posts);
}));

lessons.title: Quiz: REST APIs
lessons.description: Test your understanding of REST API development

lessons.title: Introduction to MongoDB
lessons.description: Learn MongoDB and Mongoose ODM

lessons.title: Mongoose Models and Schemas
lessons.description: Define data models with Mongoose
lessons.content:
Installing Mongoose

npm install mongoose

Connecting to MongoDB

const mongoose = require('mongoose');

mongoose.connect('mongodb://localhost:27017/myapp', {
  useNewUrlParser: true,
  useUnifiedTopology: true
})
.then(() => console.log('MongoDB connected'))
.catch(err => console.error('MongoDB connection error:', err));

Defining a Schema

const userSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: {
    type: String,
    required: [true, 'Name is required'],
    trim: true,
    minlength: 2,
    maxlength: 50
  },
  email: {
    type: String,
    required: true,
    unique: true,
    lowercase: true,
    match: [/^\S+@\S+\.\S+$/, 'Invalid email']
  },
  age: {
    type: Number,
    min: 0,
    max: 120
  },
  isActive: {
    type: Boolean,
    default: true
  },
  createdAt: {
    type: Date,
    default: Date.now
  }
});

const User = mongoose.model('User', userSchema);
module.exports = User;

CRUD Operations with Mongoose

// Create
const user = new User({
  name: 'John Doe',
  email: 'john@example.com',
  age: 25
});
await user.save();

// Read
const users = await User.find();
const user = await User.findById(id);
const activeUsers = await User.find({ isActive: true });

// Update
await User.findByIdAndUpdate(id, { age: 26 }, { new: true });

// Delete
await User.findByIdAndDelete(id);

lessons.title: Working with SQL Databases
lessons.description: Use PostgreSQL and MySQL with Node.js

lessons.title: Database Migrations and Seeding
lessons.description: Manage database schema changes
lessons.content:
Using TypeORM for SQL Databases

npm install typeorm pg reflect-metadata

Entity Definition

import { Entity, PrimaryGeneratedColumn, Column } from 'typeorm';

@Entity()
export class User {
  @PrimaryGeneratedColumn()
  id: number;

  @Column()
  name: string;

  @Column({ unique: true })
  email: string;

  @Column({ default: true })
  isActive: boolean;
}

Creating Migrations

// Run migration
typeorm migration:create -n CreateUsersTable

// Generated migration file
import { MigrationInterface, QueryRunner, Table } from 'typeorm';

export class CreateUsersTable1234567890 implements MigrationInterface {
  public async up(queryRunner: QueryRunner): Promise {
    await queryRunner.createTable(
      new Table({
        name: 'users',
        columns: [
          { name: 'id', type: 'int', isPrimary: true, isGenerated: true },
          { name: 'name', type: 'varchar' },
          { name: 'email', type: 'varchar', isUnique: true },
          { name: 'isActive', type: 'boolean', default: true }
        ]
      })
    );
  }

  public async down(queryRunner: QueryRunner): Promise {
    await queryRunner.dropTable('users');
  }
}

lessons.title: JWT Authentication
lessons.description: Implement JSON Web Token authentication
lessons.content:
Installing Dependencies

npm install jsonwebtoken bcryptjs

Password Hashing

const bcrypt = require('bcryptjs');

// Hash password before saving
const saltRounds = 10;
const hashedPassword = await bcrypt.hash(plainPassword, saltRounds);

// Compare password during login
const isMatch = await bcrypt.compare(plainPassword, hashedPassword);

Generating JWT Tokens

const jwt = require('jsonwebtoken');

// Sign token
const token = jwt.sign(
  { userId: user.id, email: user.email },
  process.env.JWT_SECRET,
  { expiresIn: '24h' }
);

// Verify token
try {
  const decoded = jwt.verify(token, process.env.JWT_SECRET);
  console.log(decoded); // { userId: ..., email: ..., iat: ..., exp: ... }
} catch (err) {
  console.error('Invalid token');
}

Authentication Middleware

const authenticateToken = (req, res, next) => {
  const authHeader = req.headers['authorization'];
  const token = authHeader && authHeader.split(' ')[1];

  if (!token) {
    return res.status(401).json({ error: 'Access token required' });
  }

  jwt.verify(token, process.env.JWT_SECRET, (err, user) => {
    if (err) {
      return res.status(403).json({ error: 'Invalid token' });
    }
    req.user = user;
    next();
  });
};

// Protected route
router.get('/profile', authenticateToken, (req, res) => {
  res.json({ user: req.user });
});

Complete Auth Flow

// Register
router.post('/register', async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password, name } = req.body;
  
  // Hash password
  const hashedPassword = await bcrypt.hash(password, 10);
  
  // Save user
  const user = await User.create({
    email,
    password: hashedPassword,
    name
  });
  
  // Generate token
  const token = jwt.sign(
    { userId: user.id },
    process.env.JWT_SECRET,
    { expiresIn: '24h' }
  );
  
  res.status(201).json({ token, user });
});

// Login
router.post('/login', async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  
  // Find user
  const user = await User.findOne({ email });
  if (!user) {
    return res.status(401).json({ error: 'Invalid credentials' });
  }
  
  // Check password
  const isMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, user.password);
  if (!isMatch) {
    return res.status(401).json({ error: 'Invalid credentials' });
  }
  
  // Generate token
  const token = jwt.sign(
    { userId: user.id },
    process.env.JWT_SECRET,
    { expiresIn: '24h' }
  );
  
  res.json({ token, user });
});

lessons.title: Role-Based Access Control
lessons.description: Implement authorization with roles and permissions

lessons.title: Session-Based Authentication
lessons.description: Alternative authentication with sessions
lessons.content:
Session Authentication with express-session

npm install express-session connect-mongo

Session Setup

const session = require('express-session');
const MongoStore = require('connect-mongo');

app.use(session({
  secret: process.env.SESSION_SECRET,
  resave: false,
  saveUninitialized: false,
  store: MongoStore.create({
    mongoUrl: process.env.MONGODB_URI,
    ttl: 24 * 60 * 60 // 1 day
  }),
  cookie: {
    maxAge: 1000 * 60 * 60 * 24, // 1 day
    httpOnly: true,
    secure: process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production'
  }
}));

Login with Sessions

router.post('/login', async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  
  const user = await User.findOne({ email });
  if (!user || !(await bcrypt.compare(password, user.password))) {
    return res.status(401).json({ error: 'Invalid credentials' });
  }
  
  // Store user in session
  req.session.userId = user.id;
  req.session.email = user.email;
  
  res.json({ message: 'Logged in successfully', user });
});

router.post('/logout', (req, res) => {
  req.session.destroy();
  res.json({ message: 'Logged out successfully' });
});

Session Authentication Middleware

const requireAuth = (req, res, next) => {
  if (!req.session.userId) {
    return res.status(401).json({ error: 'Not authenticated' });
  }
  next();
};

router.get('/profile', requireAuth, async (req, res) => {
  const user = await User.findById(req.session.userId);
  res.json({ user });
});

lessons.title: Quiz: Authentication
lessons.description: Test your knowledge of authentication and authorization

sections.title: Advanced Topics
sections.description: Master advanced Node.js concepts and best practices

lessons.title: Asynchronous Patterns
lessons.description: Callbacks, Promises, and async/await

lessons.title: Streams and Buffers
lessons.description: Work with large data efficiently
lessons.content:
What are Streams?

Streams are objects that let you read or write data piece by piece, without loading everything into memory.

Types of Streams

  • Readable: Read data (e.g., fs.createReadStream)
  • Writable: Write data (e.g., fs.createWriteStream)
  • Duplex: Both read and write
  • Transform: Modify data while reading/writing

Reading Files with Streams

const fs = require('fs');

// Read large file efficiently
const readStream = fs.createReadStream('large-file.txt', {
  encoding: 'utf8',
  highWaterMark: 64 * 1024 // 64KB chunks
});

readStream.on('data', (chunk) => {
  console.log('Received chunk:', chunk.length, 'bytes');
});

readStream.on('end', () => {
  console.log('Finished reading file');
});

readStream.on('error', (err) => {
  console.error('Error:', err);
});

Piping Streams

const readStream = fs.createReadStream('input.txt');
const writeStream = fs.createWriteStream('output.txt');

// Copy file using streams
readStream.pipe(writeStream);

// Multiple pipes
const zlib = require('zlib');
const gzip = zlib.createGzip();

fs.createReadStream('input.txt')
  .pipe(gzip)
  .pipe(fs.createWriteStream('input.txt.gz'));

Buffers

// Create buffer
const buf1 = Buffer.from('Hello');
const buf2 = Buffer.alloc(10); // 10 bytes of zeros

// Work with buffers
console.log(buf1.toString()); // 'Hello'
console.log(buf1.length); // 5
console.log(buf1[0]); // 72 (ASCII code for 'H')

// Concatenate buffers
const buf3 = Buffer.concat([buf1, Buffer.from(' World')]);
console.log(buf3.toString()); // 'Hello World'

lessons.title: Testing Node.js Applications
lessons.description: Write unit and integration tests

lessons.title: Performance and Security
lessons.description: Optimize performance and secure your applications
lessons.content:
Performance Best Practices

  • Use compression: Compress responses with gzip
  • Caching: Cache frequently accessed data
  • Database indexing: Index frequently queried fields
  • Connection pooling: Reuse database connections
  • Cluster mode: Use multiple CPU cores

Compression Middleware

npm install compression

const compression = require('compression');
app.use(compression());

Security Best Practices

  • Helmet.js: Set secure HTTP headers
  • Rate limiting: Prevent brute force attacks
  • Input validation: Validate and sanitize all inputs
  • CORS: Configure Cross-Origin Resource Sharing
  • Environment variables: Never hardcode secrets

Security Middleware

npm install helmet express-rate-limit cors

const helmet = require('helmet');
const rateLimit = require('express-rate-limit');
const cors = require('cors');

// Security headers
app.use(helmet());

// CORS
app.use(cors({
  origin: process.env.ALLOWED_ORIGINS.split(','),
  credentials: true
}));

// Rate limiting
const limiter = rateLimit({
  windowMs: 15 * 60 * 1000, // 15 minutes
  max: 100 // limit each IP to 100 requests per windowMs
});
app.use('/api/', limiter);

Environment Variables

npm install dotenv

// .env file
PORT=3000
DB_HOST=localhost
DB_PASSWORD=secret123
JWT_SECRET=your-secret-key

// Load in app
require('dotenv').config();

const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;
const dbPassword = process.env.DB_PASSWORD;

lessons.description: Deploy Node.js applications to production

quizzes.title: Node.js Basics Quiz
quizzes.description: Test your understanding of Node.js fundamentals

questions.question: What is Node.js?

options.text: A JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine

questions.explanation: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime environment that executes JavaScript code outside of a web browser, built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine.

questions.question: Which module system does Node.js use by default?
questions.explanation: Node.js uses CommonJS module system by default, with module.exports and require().

questions.question: Node.js is single-threaded.
questions.explanation: True. Node.js runs on a single thread using an event loop for asynchronous operations.

quizzes.title: Express.js Quiz
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of Express framework

questions.question: What is Express.js?

options.text: A minimal web framework for Node.js

questions.explanation: Express.js is a minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework.

questions.question: Middleware functions have access to which objects?
questions.explanation: Middleware functions have access to the request object (req), response object (res), and next middleware function (next).

quizzes.title: REST APIs Quiz
quizzes.description: Test your understanding of REST API development

questions.question: Which HTTP method is used to create a new resource?
questions.explanation: POST is used to create new resources in RESTful APIs.

questions.question: What status code indicates a successful resource creation?
questions.explanation: 201 Created indicates that a resource has been successfully created.

quizzes.title: Authentication Quiz
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge of authentication and authorization

questions.question: What does JWT stand for?
questions.explanation: JWT stands for JSON Web Token, a compact way to securely transmit information between parties.

questions.question: Passwords should be stored in plain text in the database.
questions.explanation: False. Passwords should always be hashed using algorithms like bcrypt before storing in the database.
